revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=August 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2014}} {{Infobox climber | image = Zac Zaharias.jpg | caption = Lieutenant Colonel Zac Zaharias, retired senior Australian Army officer, veteran Australian mountain climber, adventurer and outdoor trainer. | name = Zac Zaharias | nationality = Australian | birth_date = {{Birth date|df=yes|1956|07|21}} | birth_place = | death_date = | death_place = | typeofclimber = Mountaineer | highestgrade = | knownfor = | firstascents = | namedroutes = | majorascents = [[Mount Everest]] (2001) }}
[[Lieutenant Colonel]] '''Zac Zaharias''' [[Conspicuous Service Medal]] (21 July 1956{{spaced ndash}}) is a retired senior [[Australian Army]] officer, veteran Australian [[Mountaineering|mountain climber]], adventurer and outdoor trainer. Zaharias was part of the Australian Army expedition that climbed [[Mount Everest]] in 2010. Zaharias was one of six Australians and two Britons who made it to the summit on 25 May 2010 with an expedition led by South Australian [[Duncan Chessell]].<ref name=DefenceNews></ref> Zaharias is a graduate of the [[Royal Military College, Duntroon]] (1974—77) and has served with the [[Special Air Service Regiment]], at the [[Australian Defence Force Academy]] and with the [[United Nations]].<ref name=OutDoorInsights>{{cite news | publisher = Outdoor Insights Pty Ltd | url = http://www.outdoorinsights.com.au/Our_Team.html | title = OUR TEAM: Brief profiles of key Outdoor Insights staff... | date = 2015 | accessdate = 3 October 2015}}</ref> Zaharias is the president of the Canberra Climbers Association.<ref name=CT2014>{{cite news | publisher = ''Canberra Times'' | url = http://www.canberratimes.com.au/act-news/its-too-easy-to-go-to-mt-everest-now-says-canberra-mountaineer-20140422-372i3.html | title = ''It's too easy to go to Mt Everest now,'' says Canberra mountaineer | date = 23 April 2014 | accessdate = 3 October 2015}}</ref><ref name=NMA2009>{{cite AV media | people = Professor Ken Baldwin, Geoff Bartram, Duncan Chessell, Patrick Cullinan, Lincoln Hall, Greg Mortimer, Zac Zaharias, Matthew Higgins (Curator) | title = Australians in the Himalayas | url = http://www.nma.gov.au/audio/transcripts/NMA_Australians_Himalayas_20091011.html | medium = Audio on demand transcript | publisher = National Museum of Australia | location = Canberra | date = 11 October 2009 }}</ref>
==Expeditions==
Zaharias is one of Australia’s leading high altitude climbers, his first expedition to the Himalayas was in the early ’80s and he was a driving force of the Australian Army Alpine Club for many years.<ref name=NMA2009></ref> He has participated in 17 major high altitude expeditions and has been leader or deputy leader on 13 of his expeditions. He has summited six of the world’s fourteen peaks above 8000 metres. His notable ascents include:<ref name=EMTeam>{{cite news | publisher = ''Expedition and Wilderness Medicine Pty Ltd'' | url = http://www.expeditionmedicine.com.au/index.php/team/index/p-004.html | title = Expedition Medicine: Meet the Team | date = 23 April 2014 | accessdate = 3 October 2015}}</ref> * 2nd Australian ascent of Mt McKinley (6192m) in Alaska in 1982; * 2nd ascent of the south-east face of Nilgiri North (7061m) in 1983; * 1st Australian ascents of Broad Peak (8046m) in 1986 and Dhaulagiri I (8167m) in 1997; * 1st ascent of the north face of Kedarnath (6940m) in 1991 on a joint Indo-Australian Military Expedition; and * an ascent of Spantik Peak (7028m) in Pakistan in 2011 on an Australian-Pakistan Military Expedition.
On an expedition to Ganesh IV in 1981 Zaharias was with fellow climbers Maila Pemba, David Simpson and Jim Truscott who were left stranded, without equipment and ''lucky to be alive'' after the avalanche destroyed the camp two killing David Sloane.<ref name=Steffen>{{cite book
| last = Steffen | first = Will | date = 2010 | title = Himalayan Dreaming: Australian Mountaineering in the Great Ranges of Asia, 1922-1990 | url = https://books.google.com.au/books?id=vbj3AQAAQBAJ | location = Canberra | publisher = ANU E Press | page = 220 | isbn = 1921666161}}</ref>
In 2001 on the Army Alpine Association expedition, one of the team members and two people accompanying him were killed in an avalanche while they were doing an acclimatisation trek in Nepal several hundred kilometres away from Everest.<ref name=ABC2009>{{cite news | publisher = ''Australian Broadcasting Corporation'' | url = http://www.abc.net.au/stateline/act/content/2006/s2705052.htm | title = Mountain Men | date = 2 October 2009 | accessdate = 3 October 2015}}</ref><ref name=TheAge>{{cite news
| publisher = ''The Age''
| url = http://www.theage.com.au/articles/2003/06/02/1054406130418.html | title = Change to ADF training after trek tragedy | date = 3 June 2003 | accessdate = 3 October 2015}}</ref> ==Everest==
Zaharias became the second [[Australian Army]] representative and the oldest Australian to summit Everest on his third attempt in 2010.<ref name=DefenceNews></ref>
His first attempt was in 1988 as part of the Australian Bicentennial expedition. Zaharias got to within 300m of the Summit. RAAF Sergeant Brian Laursen and Paul Bain made it to the top. His second attempt was in 2001 when he was the leader of the Army Alpine Association team. In that attempt Lieutenant-Colonel Pat Cullinan made the summit on 25 May 2010. Major Zaharias got to within 100m from the summit.<ref name=DefenceNews></ref><ref name=NMA2009></ref>
The Defence Newspaper said that "It was third time lucky for Major Zac Zaharias when he eventually made it to the top of the world – conquering Mount Everest – after falling agonisingly short on two earlier attempts. When he got there, though, there was no hooting and hollering, no singing, no dancing – just relief and a deep sense of accomplishment, and a brief moment to take in the breath-taking view before focusing on a safe descent."<ref name=DefenceNews>{{cite news | publisher = ''Department of Defence (Australia)'' | url = http://www.defence.gov.au/defencenews/stories/2010/Jun/0610a.htm | title = Third time tops it all | date = 10 June 2010 | accessdate = 3 October 2015}}</ref>
